content: The "Next Steps for Credit Availability Act" allows business development companies to own investment advisers and expands access to capital for these companies. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO EXPAND ACCESS TO CAPITAL FOR BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT COMPANIES. Amendments to the Investment Company Act of 1940 increase the limit on indebtedness for business development companies and exempt them from certain regulations. SEC. 4. PARITY FOR BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT COMPANIES REGARDING OFFERING RULES. This section ensures equal treatment for business development companies in terms of offering rules. The Securities and Exchange Commission must revise rules to allow business development companies to use securities offering rules available to other issuers required to file reports under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. This includes revising rule 405 under the Securities Act of 1933 to remove the exclusion of business development companies from the definition of a well-known seasoned issuer. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise rules to allow business development companies to use securities offering rules available to other issuers. This includes removing exclusions for business development companies from various rules under the Securities Act of 1933. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise rules under the Securities Act of 1933 to include business development companies in various securities offering rules, removing exclusions for them. This includes revising rules related to registration for securities, exceptions for business development companies, and filing processes for prospectuses. Form N-2 will be revised to incorporate by reference reports and documents filed under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 for qualifying business development companies. Well-known seasoned issuers may file automatic shelf offerings on Form N-2.
